titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Marian Swerdlow Papers WAG.367
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-04-04 16:29:44 -0400.

change.item: Record updated by Rachel Searcy to reflect 2024 accretion

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 10 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box

did.abstract: Marian Swerdlow (1949 - ) is a sociologist, educator, a former New York City subway conductor, and a former member of the Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100. Swerdlow was an active supporter of Local 100 opposition campaigns led by Arnold Cherry in the late 1970s and 1980s, and started the newsletter Hell on Wheels to disseminate information and support the slate of opposition candidates that later became the reform caucus New Directions. She published a memoir of her experiences, Underground Woman: My Four Years as a New York City Subway Conductor in 1998. Swerdlow taught sociology at the State University College at Buffalo, and high school social studies in the Brooklyn. As a member of the United Federation of Teachers, she was involved in the reform movements Teachers for a Just Contract and the Movement of Rank and File Educators (MORE). The Marian Swerdlow Papers (dated 1978-2020) consists of materials collected by Swerdlow documenting her experiences as a subway conductor, as well as the opposition groups and reform movements within TWU Local 100 in the late 20th century. Materials include newsletters, newspaper clippings, notebooks from meetings,journals, and ephemera concerning actions, strikes, contract campaigns, challenges to incumbent union leadership, Local 100 elections, Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) engagement with transit workers, and the safety and working conditions of transit workers. Opposition newsletters include Hell on Wheels and Rank and File Advocate. The collection also includes sociological papers and conference presentations by Swerdlow on various labor topics based in part on her personal experiences. This collection documents the working conditions of transit workers, coverage of TWU in the media, and the conflict in leadership within Local 100 between the incumbent Willie James and the reform movement of New Directions. The collection also documents Swerdlow's career as an educator, particularly her involvement with the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) and the UFT reform group Teachers for a Just Contract. These materials include ephemera, notes, and correspondence, and document the conversations amongst rank and file educators on working conditions such as seniority, class size, classroom supplies, class preparation time, workday length, evaluations, and terminations.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Marian Swerdlow Papers (dated 1978-2020) consists of materials collected by Swerdlow documenting her experiences as a subway conductor, as well as the opposition groups and reform movements within TWU Local 100 in the late 20th century. Materials include newsletters, newspaper clippings, notebooks from meetings,journals, and ephemera concerning actions, strikes, contract campaigns, challenges to incumbent union leadership, Local 100 elections, Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) engagement with transit workers, and the safety and working conditions of transit workers. Opposition newsletters include Hell on Wheels and Rank and File Advocate. The collection also includes sociological papers and conference presentations by Swerdlow on various labor topics based in part on her personal experiences. This collection documents the working conditions of transit workers, coverage of TWU in the media, and the conflict in leadership within Local 100 between the incumbent Willie James and the reform movement of New Directions. The collection also documents Swerdlow's career as an educator, particularly her involvement with the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) and the UFT reform group Teachers for a Just Contract. These materials include ephemera, notes, and correspondence, and document the conversations amongst rank and file educators on working conditions such as seniority, class size, classroom supplies, class preparation time, workday length, evaluations, and terminations.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into two series:
Series I. Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100 Records
Series II. United Federation of Teachers and Teachers for a Just Contract Records.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Marian Swerdlow in July 2021; the accession number associated with this gift is 2021.032. Swerdlow donated an accretion in March 2024; the accession number associated with this gift is 2024.020.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Marian Swerdlow Papers; WAG 367; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning materials were rehoused in archival boxes, maintaining the donor's original folders and original order. Materials were described on the collection-level with a folder-level inventory.

In April 2024, an accretion of mateials was rehoused in archival boxes and folders. Materials documenting Swerdlow's involvement with the Transport Workers Union of America were intellectually grouped with the original donation in the newly created Series I. New materials documenting Swerdlow's involvement with the United Federation of Teachers and Teachers for a Just Contract were described as Series II. The collection title was also revised from the Marian Swerdlow Collection on Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100 to the Marian Swerdlow Papers to more accurately reflect the collection in its entirety.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Marian Swerdlow (1949 - ) is a sociologist, educator, a former New York City subway conductor, and a former member of the Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100. Swerdlow was an active supporter of Local 100 opposition campaigns led by Arnold Cherry in the late 1970s and 1980s, and started the newsletter Hell on Wheels to disseminate information and support the slate of opposition candidates that later became the reform caucus New Directions. She published a memoir of her experiences, Underground Woman: My Four Years as a New York City Subway Conductor in 1998. Swerdlow taught sociology at the State University College at Buffalo, and high school social studies in the Brooklyn. As a member of the United Federation of Teachers, she was involved in the reform movements Teachers for a Just Contract and the Movement of Rank and File Educators (MORE).

did.unittitle: Series I. Transport Workers Union of America (TWU), Local 100 Records

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in the roughly chronological order in which they were received from the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials collected by Swerdlow documenting her experiences as a subway conductor, as well as the opposition groups and reform movements within TWU Local 100 in the late 20th century. Materials include newsletters, newspaper clippings, notebooks from meetings, and ephemera concerning actions, strikes, contract campaigns, challenges to incumbent union leadership, Local 100 elections, Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) engagement with transit workers, and the safety and working conditions of transit workers. Opposition newsletters include Hell on Wheels and Rank and File Advocate. The collection also includes sociological papers and conference presentations by Swerdlow on various labor topics based in part on her personal experiences. This collection documents the working conditions of transit workers, coverage of TWU in the media, and the conflict in leadership within Local 100 between the incumbent Willie James and the reform movement of New Directions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Swerdlow's career as an educator, particularly her involvement with the United Federation of Teachers (UFT) and the UFT reform group Teachers for a Just Contract. These materials include ephemera, notes, and correspondence, and document the conversations amongst rank and file educators on working conditions such as seniority, class size, classroom supplies, class preparation time, workday length, evaluations, and terminations.
